title: Ticket #555: strptime() failure in stduniv with gnu extensions
description:
The strptime() function in glibc apparently has some gnu extensions associated with its definition that cause it to fail when used in a condor_compile'd program.

See rust ticket for many details.
remarks:
2009-Sep-30 15:10:25 by psilord:
Ok, I've p reproduced the error in this setup: 

Linux nmi-v001 > uname -a
Linux nmi-v001 2.6.9-55.EL.100hz #1 Tue Mar 31 20:07:07 CDT 2009 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux
Linux nmi-v001 > condor_version
$CondorVersion: 7.1.4 Nov 10 2008 BuildID: 113473 $
$CondorPlatform: X86_64-LINUX_RHEL3 $

2009-Sep-30 15:41:19 by psilord:
Ok, I figured it out.

The bug is that the %z format option, which is a GNU Extension to the POSIX interface to strptime in order to support strftime(), isn't implemented in the revision of glibc (2.3.2, actually 2.3.2.27.9.7) used in RHEL3. I looked at the glibc code itself, and %z isn't in the cases of the switch statement.

Since the RHEL3 full port of Condor uses that exact revision of glibc, any program condor_compiled on a RHEL3 port of Condor using strptime() and the %z format option is doomed to fail. I have in fact reproduced this problem outside of condor_compile all together, removing Condor from the equation (to be specific, on a real RHEL3 machine running the user's test case).

It appears in my testing that the RHEL5 full port of Condor doesn't suffer from this problem and the glibc on that machine implements %z.

2009-Sep-30 15:45:58 by psilord:
My advice, mentioned in the ticket, is to use the POSIX format specifiers instead of the GNU extensions and/or upgrade to the RHEL5 full port of Condor.
